question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of behavioral problems. His mother says that he has frequent angry outbursts and gets into fights with his classmates. He constantly complains of feeling hungry, even after eating a full meal. He has no siblings, and both of his parents are healthy. He is at the 25^th percentile for height and is above the 95^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows central obesity, undescended testes, almond-shaped eyes, and a thin upper lip. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of behavioral problems. His mother says that he has frequent angry outbursts and gets into fights with his classmates. He constantly complains of feeling hungry, even after eating a full meal. He has no siblings, and both of his parents are healthy. He is at the 25th percentile for height and is above the 95th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows central obesity, undescended testes, almond-shaped eyes, and a thin upper lip. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
hint: This boy presents with behavioral problems, short stature, hyperphagia, facial dysmorphism, and cryptorchidism, which is consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Prader-Willi syndrome, and recall its genetic etiology.

answers.content: De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome
answers.explanation_why: Sporadic, de novo mutations of the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome are responsible for most cases of Rett syndrome. Germline mutations inherited from phenotypically normal mothers can also occur, but are rare. Rett syndrome almost exclusively affects females and manifests with progressive loss of intelligence, cognitive abilities, and fine motor skills.

answers.content: Microdeletion of long arm of chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Microdeletion of the long arm of chromosome 7, which contains the elastin gene, causes Williams syndrome. This patient's constellation of features does not suggest Williams syndrome.

answers.content: Mutation of FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15
answers.explanation_why: Mutation of the FBN-1 gene on chromosome 15 results in Marfan syndrome. Because this condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner with variable penetrance, one parent is usually affected, which is not the case here. This child's features do not resemble those found in Marfan syndrome.

Mitotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 results in mosaic trisomy 21, which accounts for 1–2% of trisomy 21 cases. In these cases, two cell lines and thus two karyotypes are present, and the phenotypic expression varies according to the ratio of healthy to trisomic cells. Although cryptorchidism and obesity are common features of trisomy 21, this patient's behavioral problems, hyperphagia, and facial dysmorphism suggest a different genetic condition.

answers.content: Deletion of Phe508 on maternal chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the phenylalanine codon at position 508 of the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 is the most common mutation in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). Because CF is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, the deletion would need to be present in both the maternal and paternal chromosomes for the fetus to develop the condition. This patient's constellation of features is not consistent with cystic fibrosis.

Mutation or deletion on the paternal chromosome 15 (at 15q11–q13) in combination with genomic imprinting (i.e., silencing) via methylation of the maternal chromosome 15 (also at 15q11–q13) results in Prader-Willi syndrome.

Imprinting of the paternal allele in combination with a microdeletion of the same region on the maternal chromosome 15 would result in Angelman syndrome.

images.title: Etiology of Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lump in her right breast. Fifteen years ago, she was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of her left distal femur. Her father died of an adrenocortical carcinoma at the age of 41 years. Examination shows a 2-cm, firm, immobile mass in the lower outer quadrant of the right breast. A core needle biopsy of the mass shows adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a defect in which of the following genes?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lump in her right breast. Fifteen years ago, she was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of her left distal femur. Her father died of an adrenocortical carcinoma at the age of 41 years. Examination shows a 2-cm, firm, immobile mass in the lower outer quadrant of the right breast. A core needle biopsy of the mass shows adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a defect in which of the following genes?
hint: This patient presents with a personal history of malignancy (osteosarcoma, adenocarcinoma) at an early age and a family history of early-onset malignancy (adrenocortical carcinoma). The age of onset and type of malignancies are highly suggestive of the autosomal dominant disorder Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Li-Fraumeni syndrome, and recall its associated genetic mutation.

answers.explanation_why: RET proto-oncogene mutations are associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. This patient has no history of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma or primary hyperparathyroidism, making MEN 2A and MEN 2B unlikely.

KRAS proto-oncogene encodes a GTPase that regulates cellular growth. KRAS proto-oncogene mutations are associated with colon cancer, non-small cell lung cancers, and pancreatic cancers, but not with breast, adrenal or bone malignancies.

Genetic analysis in this patient is most likely to show a TP53 tumor suppressor gene mutation resulting in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. TP53 regulates cell apoptosis and cell cycle arrest at the G1 phase (by activating p21) and inhibits entry in the S phase of the cell cycle. In the absence of the normal activated p53 protein, cells containing damaged DNA can proliferate, resulting in malignant transformation. Common malignancies include osteosarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and adrenocortical carcinomas.

See “Overview of tumor suppressor genes” table.

BRCA mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and ovarian cancer, as well as colon, pancreas, stomach and prostate cancer. They are not associated with osteosarcoma and adrenocortical carcinoma.

MLH1 is a DNA mismatch repair gene. Mutation in this gene is associated with Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and breast cancer. Osteosarcoma and adrenocortical carcinoma are more commonly associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
Mutations in the PTEN gene are associated with prostate cancer and Cowden syndrome. Osteosarcoma and adrenal tumors are not usually associated.

Rb gene encodes retinoblastoma protein, which deactivates E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing G1 phase to S phase transition. Mutations in Rb gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma but not with breast or adrenal cancers.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a rash on the elbows for several months. A biopsy of the affected area shows a thinned stratum granulosum as well as retained nuclei and spongiotic clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a rash on the elbows for several months. A biopsy of the affected area shows a thinned stratum granulosum as well as retained nuclei and spongiotic clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
hint: Thinning of the stratum granulosum, parakeratotic stratum corneum (retained nuclei), and clusters of neutrophils in the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses) on this patient's skin biopsy are highly suggestive of psoriasis.
learning_objective: Recognize psoriasis, and recall its associated conditions.

answers.explanation_why: Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy seen in up to ⅓ of patients with psoriasis. Apart from skin involvement, common findings in psoriatic arthritis include asymmetric arthritis, nail lesions, inflamed, sausage-like fingers (dactylitis), and pencil-in-cup deformity of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) on x-ray.

Gliadin hypersensitivity is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, an autoimmune blistering skin disorder. Unlike this patient's findings, skin biopsy in dermatitis herpetiformis shows subepidermal clefting and blistering with IgA deposition at dermal papillae.

Hepatitis C virus infection is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of lichen planus, a skin condition that can also manifest on the elbows. However, skin biopsy in lichen planus shows hypergranulosis rather than this patient's thinning of the stratum granulosum.

Hashimoto thyroiditis does not occur at higher rates in patients with psoriasis but is associated with other autoimmune conditions, including vitiligo. Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin caused by destruction or dysfunction of melanocytes, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.

Parkinson disease is not associated with psoriasis but does often occur in patients with seborrheic dermatitis. This inflammatory skin condition causes recurring itchy and/or burning flares that show erythematous, patchy scaling, or greasy yellow crust on examination, unlike this patient's presentation.

Insulin resistance (e.g., diabetes or Cushing syndrome) is not associated with psoriasis but is characteristic of acanthosis nigricans. However, acanthosis nigricans does not typically manifest on the elbows. Additionally, skin biopsy in acanthosis nigricans shows acanthosis.
answers.explanation_but: Acanthosis nigricans is commonly due to an underlying malignancy (especially gastric cancer).

question_text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic blister formation. Physical examination shows multiple 1–3 cm bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds. Gentle rubbing of the skin does not result in sloughing of the epidermis. Immunofluorescence studies of a perilesional skin biopsy specimen are most likely to show deposition of antibodies in which of the following areas?
content_preview: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic blister formation. Physical examination shows multiple 1–3 cm bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds. Gentle rubbing of the skin does not result in sloughing of the epidermis. Immunofluorescence studies of a perilesional skin biopsy specimen are most likely to show deposition of antibodies in which of the following areas?
hint: The patient presents with large, pruritic bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds, sparing the mouth. Nikolsky sign is negative. These clinical features are typical of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease, most common in older adults.
learning_objective: Recognize bullous pemphigoid, and recall its immunofluorescence findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Direct immunofluorescence in bullous pemphigoid reveals linear deposition of IgG and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction. The bullae are formed due to an immune reaction caused by autoantibodies directed against bullous pemphigoid antigen 1 and bullous pemphigoid antigen 2 (components of the hemidesmosome). Microscopic examination of a blistering lesion usually reveals the presence of eosinophils with the separation of tissue layers subepidermally causing tense bullae.

Bullous pemphigoid is a benign disease that usually responds well to treatment with high-dose topical steroids.

images.title: Bullous pemphigoid
images.description: A: Microscopy (100x magnification) with immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the basement membrane of a skin tissue sample.B: Microscopy (200x magnification) with indirect immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the epidermal junction of a skin tissue sample.

answers.explanation_why: Deposition of antibodies between epidermal keratinocytes is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, characterized by acantholysis that results in the formation of intraepidermal blisters and bullae. Acantholysis is induced by IgG antibodies directed against desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1, which usually mediate keratinocyte adherence. Blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and nonpruritic rather than tense and pruritic as seen here. Moreover, lesions typically first present on the oral mucosa and the Nikolsky sign is positive.

images.title: Pemphigus vulgaris
images.description: Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

answers.explanation_why: No staining on direct immunofluorescence is observed in Stevens Johnson syndrome as the pathogenesis is thought to be a T-cell mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which does not involve antibody antigen interaction. Although bullae are present in this disease, other skin features include extensive, full-thickness epidermal necrosis and sloughing (resembling large superficial burns) and mucosal involvement along with a positive Nikolsky sign.

images.title: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (severe Stevens-Johnson syndrome)
images.description: Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

answers.explanation_why: Granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae are observed in dermatitis herpetiformis with antibodies directed against epidermal transglutaminase. Although dermatitis herpetiformis presents with pruritic blisters, they are usually in grouped (herpetiform) arrangement and the most commonly involved sites include elbows, dorsal forearms, knees, scalp, back, and buttocks. Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease.

images.title: Dermatitis herpetiformis
images.description: Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

answers.explanation_why: Perivascular immunoglobulin deposition is seen in porphyria cutanea tarda. Although it presents with bullae and blisters, they are a manifestation of chronic photosensitivity. Moreover, other skin features including increased scarring, hypertrichosis, and hyperpigmentation affecting sun-exposed areas of the body, are absent here. Lastly, porphyria cutanea tarda mainly occurs in older men with chronic alcoholism and hepatic cirrhosis.

images.title: Porphyria cutanea tarda
images.description: A fluid-filled blister is visible on the index finger. Deep ulcers and superficial erosions can be seen on the back of the left hand.These features are consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda.

question_text: One week after starting amoxicillin for sinusitis, a 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and myalgia. She has been hospitalized multiple times for recurrent streptococcal pneumonia and meningitis. She appears tired. Examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. Her antibiotic is discontinued. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her recurrent infections?
content_preview: One week after starting amoxicillin for sinusitis, a 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and myalgia. She has been hospitalized multiple times for recurrent streptococcal pneumonia and meningitis. She appears tired. Examination shows a diffuse urticarial rash. Her antibiotic is discontinued. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for her recurrent infections?
hint: This girl's history of recurrent streptococcal infections and current hypersensitivity reaction is concerning for C3 deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize C3 deficiency, and recall its role in opsonization.

answers.explanation_why: Impaired leukocyte adhesion is seen in leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1, which may present with recurrent infections during childhood. However, affected children would have a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord stump, omphalitis, and/or impaired wound healing instead of recurrent streptococcal infections.

Defective formation of the membrane attack complex occurs in terminal complement deficiency, which puts affected individuals at increased risk for Neisseria infections (e.g., Meningococcal meningitis). There is no increased susceptibility to streptococcal infections as seen in this patient.

Defective superoxide production by neutrophils and macrophages is seen in chronic granulomatous disease due to a defect in NADPH oxidase. While this condition is also characterized by recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, infection with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus) is more common, rather than the catalase-negative (e.g., Streptococcus) infections seen in this patient.

Complement factor C3 is a precursor for C3b, which plays a major role in opsonization of pathogens and immune complexes. C3 deficiency results in increased susceptibility to infections by encapsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Patients with C3 deficiency classically present with recurring severe upper respiratory infections (e.g., sinusitis), pneumonia, and meningitis, as seen in this patient.

Patients with selective IgA deficiency are usually asymptomatic but may present with recurrent airway infections (IgA plays an important role in mucosal immunity) and anaphylactic reactions. Although this patient has recurrent upper respiratory infections and current hypersensitivity reaction, her history of recurrent streptococcal meningitis suggests impaired complement-mediated immunity. Moreover, other manifestations of selective IgA deficiency such as atopy and a history of GI infections are missing in this patient.

question_text: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 41-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a 1-month history of painless, intermittent bleeding on defecation, which he discovered while wiping. His younger sister was recently diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and his mother was diagnosed with gastric cancer at 58 years of age. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Colonoscopy shows a tumor in the ascending colon. Histopathologic examination of the tumor shows a mucinous, poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A mutation of which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's family fulfills the 3-2-1 rule of Lynch syndrome: cancer in 3 affected family members, within 2 generations, and in 1 relative under 50 years of age.
learning_objective: Recognize Lynch syndrome, and recall the associated gene mutations.

answers.explanation_why:
Germline mutations in the MLH1 gene result in defective DNA mismatch repair, the underlying cause of Lynch syndrome, which is the most common hereditary form of colorectal cancer. Patients with Lynch syndrome most often have right-sided colon cancers that are diagnosed at a relatively young age (< 50 years old). It is also associated with gastric and endometrial cancer (as seen in this patient's family), as well as ovarian cancer and urothelial cancer. Screening colonoscopy may show a limited number of polyps (usually < 10) or poorly-differentiated tumor growth, as seen in this patient. Other DNA mismatch repair genes include MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.

Patients with Lynch syndrome should undergo aggressive screening, which includes annual colonoscopy, pelvic examination for women, and upper endoscopy starting at an early age.

images.title: Colorectal carcinogenesis pathways
images.description:
Top: Chromosomal instability pathway (adenoma-carcinoma sequence)
- Loss of the tumor suppressor gene, APC, results in hyperproliferative epithelium due to a loss of cellular adhesion and increased cellular proliferation. A mutation in KRAS results in unregulated cellular signaling and cellular proliferation, leading to the formation of an adenoma. Loss of the tumor suppressor genes TP53 and DCC results in the malignant transformation of an adenoma to carcinoma. The chromosomal instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in FAP (loss of APC) as well as in most cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.Bottom: Microsatellite instability pathway
- Acquired or inherited mutations in the mismatch repair genes (esp. MLH1 and MSH2) result in abnormal proliferation and the formation of adenoma and carcinoma. The microsatellite instability pathway is responsible for carcinomas in Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and a few cases of sporadic colorectal carcinoma.

answers.explanation_why: Mutation of the TP53 gene, which encodes p53, is the underlying defect that causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Affected patients typically develop sarcomas, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and/or adrenocortical carcinoma. Mutation of the TP53 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of Lynch syndrome.

Mutation of the DCC gene is responsible for the development of colon cancer. However, it is not linked to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.
Mutation of the KRAS gene is linked to the development of colon, lung, and pancreatic cancer, not to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which more commonly develop in patients with Lynch syndrome.

Mutation of the APC gene causes familial adenomatous polyposis. Affected patients have hundreds of colonic polyps that develop in childhood. These can develop into colorectal cancer, often at an early age. However, FAP does not predispose to endometrial cancer or gastric cancer, which is more commonly seen in patients with Lynch syndrome.

question_text: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of abdominal pain and foul-smelling, watery diarrhea for several days. He has not had nausea, vomiting, or bloody stools. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and recently completed a 7-day course of clindamycin for pneumonia. He has not traveled out of the United States. Which of the following toxins is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of abdominal pain and foul-smelling, watery diarrhea for several days. He has not had nausea, vomiting, or bloody stools. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and recently completed a 7-day course of clindamycin for pneumonia. He has not traveled out of the United States. Which of the following toxins is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This man has watery diarrhea following recent antibiotic use.
learning_objective: Recognize Clostridioides difficile infection, and recall its associated toxins.

answers.explanation_why: Shiga toxin is produced by Shigella spp. and enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7. This toxin inhibits the 60S subunit of ribosomes by cleaving adenine in ribosomal RNA. This causes enterocyte injury, which results in mucoid, bloody diarrhea, which is not present in this patient. This patient's recent antibiotic use is associated with a different cause of diarrhea.

Heat-stable toxin is produced by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), a common pathogen implicated in traveler's diarrhea. This toxin stimulates guanylate cyclase, which in turn increases levels of cGMP, resulting in decreased reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and water from the intestinal lumen. A patient with no history of recent travel is unlikely to have diarrhea due to ETEC.

The cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholera. This toxin stimulates adenylate cyclase, resulting in increased secretion of chloride and water into the intestinal lumen. Cholera is characterized by voluminous rice-water diarrhea and is most commonly associated with ingestion of contaminated water. Cholera is very rare in the US and there are no indications that this patient may have been exposed to contaminated water.

The cereulide toxin (a preformed toxin) is produced by Bacillus cereus, which causes acute nausea and vomiting (1–3 hours after ingestion). This toxin is typically found in reheated rice. However, this patient has no history of rice consumption or vomiting, and the time course of his illness is not consistent with B. cereus infection.

This man's presentation is consistent with Clostridioides difficile infection. Clostridioides difficile produces two toxins: toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). Both toxins depolymerize actin filaments and disrupt the cellular cytoskeleton, while toxin A also causes intestinal inflammation, leading to excessive fluid secretion. These traits cause pseudomembranous colitis and watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, as seen in this patient. Enzyme immunoassay of toxin A and B are commonly used as screening tests for C. difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD).

The alpha toxin is produced by Clostridium perfringens. This toxin is a phospholipase (lecithinase) that disrupts the cell membrane of enterocytes and causes Clostridium perfringens enterocolitis, which is characterized by abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. The diarrhea seen in Clostridium perfringens enterocolitis usually resolves within 24–48 hours and is unlikely in this patient.

question_text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3^rd percentile for length and 5^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3rd percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: A combination of hypotonia, abnormal facial grimacing suggestive of seizures, icterus, hepatomegaly, and elevated serum levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in a neonate indicates Zellweger syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Zellweger syndrome, and recall its cellular pathology.

answers.explanation_why: Centrilobular necrosis is seen in ischemic liver damage, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and various toxic liver damage cases (e.g., acetaminophen overdose). Although these conditions can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism and would not explain the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Eosinophilic apoptotic bodies (Councilman bodies) can be seen in the liver in infectious diseases like viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C) or yellow fever. Although these diseases can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism, and would not explain the accumulation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Zellweger syndrome is characterized by a defect in peroxisome formation, which prevents catabolism of VLCFAs, leading to their accumulation in cells and impairing multiple organ systems. Zellweger syndrome has a poor prognosis, with death within the first year of life and no available treatment options.

Accumulation of PAS-positive granules in hepatocytes can be seen in glycogen storage diseases, as PAS will stain polysaccharides. Although glycogen storage diseases can cause neonatal seizures, hepatomegaly, and myopathy, they are not associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentration of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Accumulation of cells with a foamy cytoplasm, i.e., lipid-laden macrophages, is seen in diseases like Niemann-Pick disease and Gaucher's disease (so-called Gaucher cells), or other causes of hepatic steatosis. Although these diseases can cause hepatomegaly and seizures, they are not generally associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentrations of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

images.title: Foam cells
images.description: Microscopic image of the splenic red pulp (H&E stain)Macrophages with a lipid-laden cytoplasm (examples: green overlay). Those cells are often referred to as “foam cells” and are a typical finding in Niemann-Pick disease.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary atresia is seen in Alagille syndrome. Although Alagille syndrome can be associated with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and dysmorphic facial features, it would not cause hypotonia or the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient. Additionally, Alagille syndrome often presents with congenital heart defects (e.g., peripheral pulmonary stenosis) and ocular findings like posterior embryotoxon.

question_text:
A 24-year-old male is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being found unconscious in a park. Serum toxicology screening is positive for a drug that increases the duration of chloride influx. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?

P_aO_2 (mm Hg)
P_aCO_2 (mm Hg)
A-a gradient (mm Hg)

A
78
51
8

B
98
38
17

C
99
33
9

D
79
29
10

E
63
49
25

F
73
38
29
content_preview: A 24-year-old male is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being found unconscious in a park. Serum toxicology screening is positive for a drug that increases the duration of chloride influx. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings? PaO2 (mm Hg) PaCO2 (mm Hg) A-a gradient (mm Hg) A 78 51 8 B 98 38 17 C 99 33 9 D 79 29 10 E 63 49 25 F 73 38 29
hint: Barbiturates are GABA_A agonists that prolong the duration of chloride channel opening. Increased chloride influx hyperpolarizes postsynaptic neurons, which reduces neuronal excitability in the brain. Overdose with barbiturates can manifest with sedation and even coma.
learning_objective: Recall the mechanism of action of barbiturates, and the arterial blood gas findings associated with a barbiturate overdose.

answers.explanation_why: Barbiturates depress the respiratory center in the medulla and thus dampen the respiratory drive (hypoventilation due to CNS depression). Hypoventilation results in hypercapnia (↑ P_aCO_2) due to decreased CO_2 elimination and hypoxemia (↓ P_aO_2). The alveolar gas equation dictates that the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen (P_AO_2) would also be decreased due to an increase in P_aCO_2. Since both P_AO_2 and P_aO_2 are decreased, the A-a gradient is usually within normal limits (5–10 mm Hg). An overdose of benzodiazepines, which increase the frequency of chloride channel opening, or opiates, which close presynaptic Ca^2+ channels and open postsynaptic K^+ channels, could also cause central hypoventilation and similar ABG findings.

Increased A-a gradient with normal P_aO_2 and P_aCO_2 can be seen during exercise as a result of increased oxygen consumption (increased respiratory quotient). A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

Normal P_aO_2, hypocapnia (↓ P_aCO_2), and a normal A-a gradient reflect hyperventilation without increased O_2 extraction. This might be seen in conditions with increased minute ventilation due to rapid respiratory rate (e.g., panic attack, initial stage of salicylate toxicity). A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

Hypoxemia (↓ P_aO_2), hypocapnia (↓ P_aCO_2), and a normal A-a gradient can be seen with low ambient oxygen pressure (e.g., at high altitude), which induces compensatory tachypnea and increased CO_2 elimination. A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

Hypoxemia (↓ P_aO_2), hypercapnia (↑ P_aCO_2), and an increased A-a gradient indicate severe ventilation-perfusion mismatch and/or decreased gas diffusion across the alveoli. This might be seen in conditions that course with decreased alveolar-capillary membrane surface area (e.g., emphysema), thickened alveolar-capillary membranes (e.g., interstitial lung disease, pulmonary fibrosis), and pulmonary edema. A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

Hypoxemia (↓ P_aO_2), normal P_aCO_2, and an increased A-a gradient indicate type 1 respiratory failure, which is typically seen with a mild ventilation-perfusion mismatch. A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a productive cough and dyspnea. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F). Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness on percussion above the right lower lobe. An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower lobe density and a small amount of fluid in the right pleural space. The patient's symptoms improve with antibiotic treatment, but he develops right-sided chest pain one week later. Pulmonary examination shows new scratchy, high-pitched breath sounds on auscultation of the right lobe. Microscopic examination of a pleural biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a productive cough and dyspnea. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F). Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness on percussion above the right lower lobe. An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower lobe density and a small amount of fluid in the right pleural space. The patient's symptoms improve with antibiotic treatment, but he develops right-sided chest pain one week later. Pulmonary examination shows new scratchy, high-pitched breath sounds on auscultation of the right lobe. Microscopic examination of a pleural biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Scratchy, high-frequency breath sounds on auscultation are called pleural friction rub, which is a sign of pleuritis.
learning_objective: Recognize fibrinous pleuritis, and recall its microscopic findings.

answers.explanation_why: A cholesterol-rich exudate in the pleural space would be suggestive of chylothorax, which is usually due to disruption of the thoracic duct (e.g., from trauma, surgery, etc). However, the onset of symptoms in this patient shortly after recovering from bacterial pneumonia is not consistent with chylothorax. Additionally, pulmonary auscultation in chylothorax would show decreased breath sounds over the affected lung rather than high-frequency scratchy sounds.

This patient's symptoms and friction rub suggest fibrinous pleuritis, a complication of parenchymal inflammation that most commonly occurs as a result of bacterial pneumonia but can also be seen as a complication of pulmonary infarction (e.g., due to pulmonary embolism). The inflammation experienced during the acute illness (in this case, pneumonia and pulmonary effusion) causes capillary vasodilation and leads to the deposition of a protein-rich, fibrinous exudate on the serosal surface of the pleura.

The presence of a dense bacterial infiltrate within the pleural space would suggest an ongoing infection. Although this patient was recently diagnosed with bacterial pneumonia, ongoing infection is unlikely given that his symptoms improved with antibiotic treatment.

The presence of caseating granulomas would suggest Mycobacterium tuberculosis or fungal infection (e.g., histoplasmosis). This patient's relatively acute presentation, clinical improvement with antibiotics, and lack of risk factors for fungal or mycobacterial infection (e.g., immune suppression) make this an unlikely finding.

Red blood cell infiltrate would be consistent with hemothorax, which can occur due to trauma, iatrogenic injury (e.g., chest tube placement), mycobacterial infection, or malignancy. However, the onset of symptoms in this patient shortly after recovering from bacterial pneumonia is not consistent with hemothorax. Additionally, pulmonary auscultation in hemothorax would show decreased breath sounds over the affected lung rather than a high-frequency scratchy sound.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was found shaking violently on the bathroom floor. His wife reports that he has become increasingly confused over the past 2 days and that he has been sleeping more than usual. He was started on chemotherapy 4 months ago for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is confused and oriented to person only. Neurological examination shows right-sided ptosis and diffuse hyperreflexia. An MRI of the brain shows disseminated, nonenhancing white matter lesions with no mass effect. A polymerase chain reaction assay of the cerebrospinal fluid confirms infection with a virus that has double-stranded, circular DNA. An antineoplastic drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after he was found shaking violently on the bathroom floor. His wife reports that he has become increasingly confused over the past 2 days and that he has been sleeping more than usual. He was started on chemotherapy 4 months ago for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He is confused and oriented to person only. Neurological examination shows right-sided ptosis and diffuse hyperreflexia. An MRI of the brain shows disseminated, nonenhancing white matter lesions with no mass effect. A polymerase chain reaction assay of the cerebrospinal fluid confirms infection with a virus that has double-stranded, circular DNA. An antineoplastic drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
hint: Common therapeutic agents for CLL include rituximab, fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, and alemtuzumab. However, only one of these drugs is known to increase the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a condition that manifests in MRI with nonenhancing lesions disseminated throughout the white matter.
learning_objective: Recognize progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Bleomycin induces the formation of free radicals, leading to breaks in DNA and halting cell replication. This agent is used to treat testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphomas, not CLL. Side effects of bleomycin include pulmonary fibrosis and hyperpigmented skin, not PML.

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as imatinib, nilotinib, and dasatinib are used in the treatment of CML, not CLL. Side effects of these agents include fluid retention, pulmonary edema, QT prolongation, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and pancytopenia. No association with PML has been found.

Etoposide and teniposide are topoisomerase II inhibitors that increase the degradation of DNA and decrease its replication. Topoisomerase II inhibitors are used in the treatment of testicular cancer, small cell lung cancer, ovarian cancer, lymphomas, and acute myeloid leukemia, but they are not commonly used to treat CLL. Furthermore, side effects of treatment with etoposide or teniposide include alopecia and myelotoxicity, not PML.

Cetuximab is a monoclonal EGFR inhibitor used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer (without KRAS mutation), as well as head and neck cancer. This agent is not used in the treatment of CLL. Side effects of cetuximab include diarrhea, skin rash, and elevated liver enzymes, not PML.

Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody against the B-cell marker CD20 that is used in the treatment of CLL. This drug is associated with an increased risk of PML, a demyelinating disease of the CNS caused by the destruction of oligodendrocytes secondary to reactivation of JC virus. Other drugs associated with an increased risk of PML include natalizumab, which is used to treat multiple sclerosis and Crohn disease. PML predominantly develops in patients with severe immunosuppression (e.g., patients with AIDS or those undergoing certain immunosuppressive therapy) and may manifest with decreased cognitive function, focal neurological deficits, and seizures, as seen here.

images.title: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted; right: diffusion-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with common variable immunodeficiency syndromeA confluent, hyperintense area (green overlay) without mass effect is seen in the right frontoparietal subcortical white matter. High signal intensity on the diffusion-weighted image (red overlay) indicates diffusion restriction.The MRI features and immunocompromised state suggest progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), even though PML lesions are typically multifocal, bilateral, and asymmetric. PML lesions generally show little or no mass effect or contrast enhancement.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing wrinkles on her face and sagging skin. She says that her skin used to be smooth and firm. Examination shows diffuse xerosis and mild atrophy, laxity, and fine wrinkles on the periorbital skin. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the development of this patient's skin findings?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing wrinkles on her face and sagging skin. She says that her skin used to be smooth and firm. Examination shows diffuse xerosis and mild atrophy, laxity, and fine wrinkles on the periorbital skin. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the development of this patient's skin findings?
hint: This woman has normal, age-related changes of the skin.
learning_objective: Recall the effects of aging on skin, and recall the role of elastin fiber assembly.

answers.explanation_why: Lysyl oxidase activity does not change with aging. In fact, lysyl oxidase activity may even increase because cross-linked collagen is more stable in older skin than younger skin. This may be partly responsible for the toughness of older skin.

Collagen biosynthesis decreases rather than increases as skin ages. Simultaneously, collagen becomes disorganized. These changes are thought to be key factors in the overall decrease in skin strength and propensity to form wrinkles observed in aged skin.

Chronological aging of the skin, in particular of the dermis, is due in large part to the decreased assembly of elastin fibers. This accounts for increased skin laxity and rigidity. Atrophy of the dermis due to loss of collagen and volume deficit as a result of reduced glycosaminoglycan synthesis further contribute to the appearance of chronologically aged skin. Moreover, aging skin is prone to xerosis secondary to moisture loss resulting from diminished lipid and sebum production at the surface.

Age-related decrease of fibroblast activity contributes in large parts to the appearance of chronologically aged skin, as fibroblast synthesize collagens and components of the extracellular matrix, such as glycosaminoglycans (e.g., hyaluronic acid). Since GAGs maintain skin structure and moisture, decreased synthesis results in loss of volume and hydration, as well as the development of wrinkles and folds. Moreover, a decrease in fibroblast activity contributes to delayed wound healing.

Increased lipofuscin deposits in organs such as heart, colon, and eyes can be found in elderly persons as a sign of normal aging. Lipofuscin is also implicated in the pigmentation changes seen in aging skin. However, it is not known to contribute to structural changes in aging skin, such as sagging and wrinkles.

The crosslinking rate of collagen fibrils typically remains unchanged or increases slightly in older individuals. This is because the activity and abundance of the enzyme responsible for catalyzing collagen and elastin crosslinking remain relatively constant with time.

question_text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening confusion, high-grade fever, and a productive cough. She has had recurrent respiratory infections and bulky, foul-smelling, oily stools since infancy. She is at the 14^th percentile for height and 8^th percentile for weight. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies 2 days after admission. Autopsy of the lungs shows bronchial mucus plugging and bronchiectasis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening confusion, high-grade fever, and a productive cough. She has had recurrent respiratory infections and bulky, foul-smelling, oily stools since infancy. She is at the 14th percentile for height and 8th percentile for weight. Despite appropriate care, the patient dies 2 days after admission. Autopsy of the lungs shows bronchial mucus plugging and bronchiectasis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's symptoms of failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and chronic steatorrhea should raise concern for cystic fibrosis.
learning_objective: Recognize cystic fibrosis, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.content: Deletion of phenylalanine codon on chromosome 7
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the codon for phenylalanine 508 in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 is the most common underlying cause of cystic fibrosis. This deletion leads to a misfolded CFTR protein that is unable to reach the cellular membrane. The CFTR protein is an important chloride channel in cell membranes, and when mutated cannot properly secrete intracellular chloride ions. This mutation causes exocrine glands to produce hyperviscous secretions that accumulate and damage different organs, mainly the lungs and pancreas.

images.title: Cystic fibrosis pathophysiology
images.description: A mutation in the CFTR gene results in defective protein synthesis and the absence of the ATP-gated chloride channel in the cell surface of epithelial cells throughout the body (intestinal and respiratory epithelia, sweat glands, exocrine pancreas, exocrine glands, and reproductive organs). Chloride and sodium are normally in equilibrium, but the accumulation of intracellular chloride due to the absence of a transporter results in the retention of intracellular sodium and water (due to osmosis). This ultimately results in hyperviscous mucus, which causes blockages of small organs and airways, inflammation, and end-organ damage.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency in adenosine deaminase leads to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although patients with SCID can present with chronic diarrhea, recurrent infections, and failure to thrive as seen in this patient, chronic steatorrhea would not be expected.

answers.content: Mutation of DNAI1 gene on chromosome 9
answers.explanation_why: Mutation of the DNAI1 gene on chromosome 9 is the underlying cause of primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can also manifest with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and mucus plugs, as seen in this patient. However, a diagnosis of primary ciliary dyskinesia would not explain this patient's chronic steatorrhea and growth failure.

answers.content: Deletion of UBE3A gene on chromosome 15
answers.explanation_why: Deletion of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15 is associated with Angelman syndrome. Unlike this patient's presentation, Angelman syndrome typically manifests with intellectual disability, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent laughing (inappropriate laughter).

Deficiency in apolipoprotein B-48 leads to abetalipoproteinemia. While affected individuals can present with severe steatorrhea and failure to thrive as seen in this patient, recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and mucus plugs would not be expected.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) results from a mutation that impairs the secretion of alpha-1 antitrypsin by hepatocytes. The lack of secretion leads to unchecked protease activity in the lungs and, consequently, the destruction of the pulmonary architecture, which can present with recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, and failure to thrive as seen in this patient. However, AATD classically causes panacinar emphysema, which this patient does not have. Moreover, this patient lacks features of hepatitis and liver cirrhosis (secondary to intracellular accumulation of alpha-1 antitrypsin), such as abdominal distension from hepatosplenomegaly or ascites.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
hint: This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, and superotemporal lens subluxation).
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall the associated defective structural protein.

answers.explanation_why: Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin.

Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen.

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). Patients with OI can present with joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but do not develop lens subluxation, high-arched palate, tall stature, or arachnodactyly. Moreover, patients with OI typically have a history of multiple fractures in the setting of minimal trauma along with blue sclerae and hearing loss. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type I collagen.
Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening headaches and increasing irritability. Examination shows bilateral papilledema. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the right temporal lobe with heterogeneous peripheral rim enhancement that crosses the midline. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass. Gross examination shows a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Microscopic examination of the mass will most likely show which of the following?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening headaches and increasing irritability. Examination shows bilateral papilledema. An MRI of the brain shows a mass in the right temporal lobe with heterogeneous peripheral rim enhancement that crosses the midline. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass. Gross examination shows a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Microscopic examination of the mass will most likely show which of the following?
hint: A brain tumor in the temporal lobe that crosses the midline and displays irregular rim enhancement is suggestive of glioblastoma, the most common type of malignant brain tumor in adults. The gross pathology findings of a poorly-demarcated mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis are consistent with this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize glioblastoma multiforme, and recall its microscopic features.

answers.content: Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions
answers.explanation_why: Spindle cells with hypercellular and hypocellular regions are characteristic of schwannomas. Schwannomas typically occur at the cerebellopontine angle and present with lateralized symptoms, especially vestibulocochlear nerve dysfunction, whereas headache, irritability, and papilledema are unlikely findings. Moreover, hemorrhage or necrosis are uncommon, as schwannomas are slow-growing tumors.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma in a 43-year-old patient
images.description: Photomicrograph of a tumor arising from the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII (H&E stain; medium magnification)A characteristic finding of neuromas is the simultaneous occurrence of areas with densely packed nuclei (palisade pattern; A) and scattered or anuclear areas (B). There is also a large number of vacuolated cells (C).

answers.content: Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells
answers.explanation_why: Closely-packed capillaries and foamy stromal cells are characteristic of hemangioblastomas, highly vascularized benign tumors most likely to be found in the cerebellum. They may present in middle age with papilledema, but patients would likely show cerebellar symptoms or polycythemia (due to production of erythropoietin). Headache and irritability as well as findings of hemorrhage and necrosis would be unlikely in a hemangioblastoma.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma (WHO grade I)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cerebellar tissue specimen (HPS stain; high magnification)Numerous polygonal neoplastic stromal cells with lipid-laden vacuoles (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen, resulting in the typical clear-cell appearance. Additionally, there is an abundance of small, thin-walled blood vessels, many of which are densely packed together (examples indicated by blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Pleomorphic cells arranged in pseudopalisades are a hallmark of glioblastoma multiforme, a highly malignant brain tumor that arises from astrocytes. Pseudopalisades are arrays of tumor cells migrating away from an area of central necrosis. Histological findings in glioblastoma multiforme vary greatly but would most likely also show microvascular proliferation as well as necrosis and hemorrhage (as already seen on gross examination).

images.title: Glioblastoma multiforme
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

answers.content: Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei
answers.explanation_why: Cells with clear cytoplasm and central round nuclei (fried egg appearance) are characteristics of oligodendrogliomas. Oligodendrogliomas would not be expected to present with bilateral papilledema but rather with seizures and sensory deficits. They are slow-growing tumors that usually occur in the frontal lobe and manifest as well-defined gray masses with areas of calcification; necrosis would not be expected.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

answers.content: Small blue cells arranged in rosettes
answers.explanation_why: Small blue cells arranged in rosettes (Homer-Wright rosettes) are characteristic of medulloblastomas. Medulloblastomas originate from the primitive neuroectoderm and are the most common malignant brain tumor in children (peak incidence 3–5 years). Medulloblastomas are typically found in the cerebellum, often compress the 4^th ventricle, and manifests with hydrocephalus and posterior vermis syndrome. On MRI they show a diffuse enhancement. The location, clinical presentation, and imaging findings of this adult patient's tumor are not consistent with medulloblastoma.

images.title: Medulloblastoma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)Densely packed, small, blue anaplastic cells are present throughout the specimen. The cells have pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei.
On the right, a vessel (its lumen mostly obstructed by eosinophilic material) can be seen.These are typical histopathological findings of medulloblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Areas of lamellated calcification are consistent with psammoma bodies, which are characteristic of meningioma and other noncerebral tumors. Meningiomas are composed of spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern. While they might also show rim enhancement on MRI, as seen in this patient, meningiomas usually appear as a homogeneous, well-defined lesion outside the brain without areas of hemorrhage and necrosis.

images.title: Meningioma
images.description: Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a brain tumor (HPS stain)Several eosinophilic cells are visible, arranged in whorls (purple overlay) and sheets. A mass of disorganized cells is visible in the top right corner (yellow overlay). The nuclei of these cells show features of malignancy (i.e., large size or high N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures). The intervening stroma contains numerous blood vessels (green overlay).Hypercellularity, whorled or sheet-like architecture, and hypervascularity are typical features of a meningioma. Psammoma bodies (not seen here) are another characteristic feature of meningioma and would appear as basophilic whorls.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing weakness in both legs for 7 days. She also reports a tingling sensation in her legs that is exacerbated by taking a hot shower. She is sexually active with one male partner and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength and clonus in both lower extremities. Patellar reflex is 4+ bilaterally and plantar reflex shows an extensor response on both sides. Abdominal reflex is absent. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to further support the diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing weakness in both legs for 7 days. She also reports a tingling sensation in her legs that is exacerbated by taking a hot shower. She is sexually active with one male partner and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength and clonus in both lower extremities. Patellar reflex is 4+ bilaterally and plantar reflex shows an extensor response on both sides. Abdominal reflex is absent. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to further support the diagnosis in this patient?
hint: This patient presents with lower leg weakness, tingling sensation exacerbated by hot shower (Uhthoff phenomenon), hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, and an absent abdominal reflex. All of these, especially in a woman of childbearing age, suggest multiple sclerosis (MS). The MRI image shows periventricular hyperintensities (T2 weighted), suggestive of demyelination.
learning_objective: Recognize multiple sclerosis, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.content: Positive antibody response to cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen in the serum
answers.explanation_why: Positive antibody response to cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen in the serum (positive rapid plasma reagin test) is a nonspecific finding in patients with syphilis. The RPR test is used to screen for syphilis as well as evaluate disease activity and monitor treatment response. Although tertiary syphilis can manifest with various neurological symptoms (neurosyphilis), it usually progresses slowly and would not be expected to show periventricular hyperintensities on MRI of the brain, as seen in this patient.

answers.content: Oligodendrocytes that stain positive for polyomavirus proteins on brain biopsy
answers.explanation_why: A finding of oligodendrocytes that stain positive for polyomavirus proteins on brain biopsy is the hallmark of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to JC virus infection. PML causes progressive neurological degeneration that can mimic multiple sclerosis. Diffusion-weighted MRI images would typically show asymmetric hyperintense lesions. However, PML is most commonly associated with AIDS, which this patient has no evidence of.

images.title: JC virus in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a brain biopsy specimen of a patient with PML (immunohistochemistry stain; 400x magnification)Glial cells infected with the JC (John Cunningham) virus are highlighted in dark brown.

answers.content: Presence of immunoglobulin bands on cerebrospinal fluid immunofixation
answers.explanation_why: The presence of immunoglobulin bands (particularly oligoclonal bands) and increased IgG production in the CSF are highly sensitive, but nonspecific, findings that support the diagnosis of MS. Lumbar puncture is indicated for patients with suspected MS who have inconclusive clinical and MRI findings. The production of multiple, nonspecific clones of IgG within the CNS is a result of intrathecal inflammation.

answers.content: Identification of gram-positive cocci in groups on blood culture
answers.explanation_why: Identification of gram-positive cocci (GPC) in groups on blood culture would not be seen in this patient who has no signs or symptoms of sepsis (e.g., fever, chills, hypotension). In addition, her neurological symptoms and imaging cannot be explained by sepsis.

answers.content: Detection of high-affinity antibodies to dsDNA in the serum
answers.explanation_why: Detection of high-affinity antibodies to dsDNA in the serum would suggest a diagnosis of SLE, which does occur predominantly in women of childbearing age and can cause neurological symptoms. This patient, however, does not have other classical features of SLE (e.g., photosensitivity, discoid rash, oral ulcers, arthritis), making another finding more likely.

images.title: White matter lesions in multiple sclerosis
images.description: MRI head (a: fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR); sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted, axial plane) of a patient with multiple sclerosisMultiple hyperintense lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are seen in the corpus callosum and periventricular white matter.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of reddish discoloration of her urine. She also has a 3-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, yellowish discoloration of the skin and eyes, and fatigue. Physical examination shows pallor and scleral icterus. The spleen is not palpable. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 2,000/mm^3, and platelet count is 80,000/mm^3. Serum LDH and unconjugated bilirubin concentrations are elevated. Addition of a serum containing anti-human globulins to a blood sample shows no agglutination. A urine dipstick shows blood; urinalysis shows no RBCs. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a thrombus in a distal branch of the superior mesenteric vein. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of reddish discoloration of her urine. She also has a 3-month history of intermittent abdominal pain, yellowish discoloration of the skin and eyes, and fatigue. Physical examination shows pallor and scleral icterus. The spleen is not palpable. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 2,000/mm3, and platelet count is 80,000/mm3. Serum LDH and unconjugated bilirubin concentrations are elevated. Addition of a serum containing anti-human globulins to a blood sample shows no agglutination. A urine dipstick shows blood; urinalysis shows no RBCs. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a thrombus in a distal branch of the superior mesenteric vein. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's red urine (with no RBCs on dipstick), fatigue, abdominal pain, jaundice, pancytopenia, evidence of intravascular hemolysis (unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated LDH), negative Coombs test, and venous thrombosis are all suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
learning_objective: Recognize paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.content: Activation and consumption of platelets and coagulation factors
answers.explanation_why: Activation and consumption of platelets and coagulation factors is a characteristic of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), an acquired coagulopathy that is frequently seen in hospitalized individuals. DIC may manifest with fatigue, jaundice, hematuria, LDH elevation, venous thrombosis, and a negative Coombs test, which are seen in this patient. However, clinical features of DIC also involve bleeding manifestations (e.g., petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses), which are not seen here. Additionally, DIC usually appears following sepsis (acutely), trauma, or malignancy (subacutely) and would not cause pancytopenia.

answers.content: Endothelial cell dysfunction from bacterial toxin production
answers.explanation_why: Endothelial cell dysfunction triggered by bacterial toxin production promotes vasoconstriction and platelet microthrombus formation. These occlude the arterioles and capillaries, resulting in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, the hallmark of hemolytic uremic syndrome. In HUS, RBCs are mechanically destroyed as they pass through the platelet microthrombi, resulting in hemolysis and end-organ ischemia. Affected patients present with thrombi, hematuria, fatigue, pallor, jaundice, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated LDH, and a negative Coombs test, all of which are seen in this patient. However, HUS is mostly seen in children and manifests after diarrheal illness with petechiae, purpura, or mucosal bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. This patient's large-vessel venous thrombosis and pancytopenia are not characteristic of HUS.

answers.content: Absence of protective factors against destruction by complement
answers.explanation_why: The absence of GPI anchor proteins CD55 and CD59, which are factors on stem cells protecting against complement destruction, is the physiological hallmark of PNH. In this condition, RBCs are especially sensitive to destruction by complement complexes, which causes intravascular hemolysis (unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated LDH), manifesting with jaundice and hemoglobinuria (dark urine). Complements also destroy leukocytes and thrombocytes, causing pancytopenia. Due to RBC destruction, less nitric oxide (NO) is generated by RBCs, and the remaining NO is scavenged by free hemoglobin (a result of hemolysis). NO is a vasodilator that causes muscle relaxation and inhibits platelet aggregation. Therefore, a lack of NO induces painful smooth muscle spasm (abdominal pain), vasoconstriction, and platelet aggregation. The latter promotes venous thrombosis, typically in unusual locations (hepatic or portal vein). Venous thrombosis formation is a severe complication and often leads to death in PNH.

answers.content: Formation of IgG antibodies against glycoprotein IIb/IIIa
answers.explanation_why: The formation of IgG antibodies against GpIIb/IIIa on platelets has been reported in patients with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and Glanzmann thrombasthenia (a very rare condition), which both cause thrombocytopenia. However, this patient does not demonstrate petechiae or ecchymoses but signs of hemolytic anemia (fatigue, jaundice, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated LDH, and hemoglobinuria) as well as pancytopenia, abdominal pain, venous thrombosis, and a negative Coombs test, all of which are inconsistent with ITP or Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

answers.content: Replacement of a single amino acid in a β-globin chain
answers.explanation_why: The replacement of a single amino acid in a β-globin chain (hydrophilic glutamic acid to hydrophobic valine) is the characteristic mutation seen in sickle cell anemia. The sickling of cells induces intravascular and extravascular hemolysis as well as RBC aggregation, causing vaso-occlusion. Affected patients may present with abdominal pain, pallor, increased LDH and unconjugated bilirubin as well as a negative Coombs test and hematuria (due to renal papillary necrosis), which are all seen in this patient. However, this patient's pancytopenia and venous thrombosis are uncharacteristic of sickle cell disease and are highly suggestive of another inherited hemolytic anemia.

question_text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of fever, vomiting, rash, and worsening confusion since this morning. On questioning, her mother reports that her last menstrual period was 1 week ago and that she recently started using tampons. She appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Her temperature is 40.4°C (104.7°F), pulse 174/minute, and blood pressure is 62/44 mm Hg. Examination shows oropharyngeal hyperemia and diffuse macular erythroderma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of fever, vomiting, rash, and worsening confusion since this morning. On questioning, her mother reports that her last menstrual period was 1 week ago and that she recently started using tampons. She appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Her temperature is 40.4°C (104.7°F), pulse 174/minute, and blood pressure is 62/44 mm Hg. Examination shows oropharyngeal hyperemia and diffuse macular erythroderma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: The sudden onset of high fever, diffuse macular erythroderma, confusion, and shock (hypotension and tachycardia) in a young girl who recently had her menstrual period raises concern for toxic shock syndrome (TSS) as a result of prolonged tampon use.
learning_objective: Recognize toxic shock syndrome, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Erythrogenic toxin production is the primary cause of streptococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS). Streptococcal TSS occurs most frequently in the setting of invasive infection due to Streptococcus pyogenes. While the clinical presentation is similar to this patient's, with fever, shock, and rash, it usually follows a cutaneous infection (impetigo) and is not typically associated with tampon use.

Lipooligosaccharide is an endotoxin found on the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria like Neisseria meningitidis. It is the primary virulence factor in meningococcemia, which would manifest with high fever, confusion, and shock. However, petechiae would be expected instead of diffuse macular erythroderma, and meningococcemia is not typically associated with tampon use.

Unregulated B cell proliferation is the primary cause of certain leukemias and B-cell lymphomas. They are unlikely to present acutely with fever, rash, confusion, and shock and are not related to tampon use. B cells are not involved in the pathophysiology of TSS.

Generalized mast cell degranulation with subsequent release of histamine, cytokines, and proteases is seen in anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis can manifest with hypotension and vomiting. However, angioedema, urticaria, and wheezing would be expected instead of this patient's macular erythroderma and fever. Furthermore, another condition is much more likely to be associated with tampon use.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a life-threatening systemic inflammatory reaction caused by bacterial exotoxins, e.g., toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) produced by Staphylococcus aureus. TSST-1 is a superantigen that triggers polyclonal T cell activation by binding to MHC II and T-cell receptors, resulting in the massive release of IL-2, IFN-γ, and TNF-α. This leads to the typical symptoms of high fever, rash, altered mental status, and shock. About half of TSS cases are caused by prolonged use of tampons over several days.

question_text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of memory loss. Three weeks ago, he had a cardiac arrest that required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous epinephrine. On mental status examination, he cannot recall objects shown to him 20 minutes earlier but vividly recalls memories from before the incident. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures of the brain is most likely affected?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of memory loss. Three weeks ago, he had a cardiac arrest that required cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous epinephrine. On mental status examination, he cannot recall objects shown to him 20 minutes earlier but vividly recalls memories from before the incident. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following structures of the brain is most likely affected?
hint: This patient presents with features of an ischemic stroke following a cardiac arrest. The short-term memory loss indicates selective neuronal necrosis of a structure within the limbic system.
learning_objective: Recognize anterograde amnesia, and recall the brain structure involved in short-term memory.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar Purkinje cells are very vulnerable to ischemic insults. However, patients with ischemic damage to this group of cells would present with intention tremor, nystagmus, and ataxia.

Microglial cells are relatively resistant to ischemic insults because they are not as metabolically active as neurons. In fact, these macrophages are typically seen in the inflammatory reaction to cellular injury after ischemia. Strokes affecting the dorsal midbrain present with Parinaud syndrome, not memory impairment.

answers.content: Internal pyramidal layer of the amygdala
answers.explanation_why: The amygdala is a complex of nuclei located in the temporal lobe, it is not composed of cellular layers like the neocortex or hippocampus. Moreover, strokes affecting the amygdala typically result in uninhibited, aggressive behavior (Kluver-Bucy syndrome).

answers.content: External pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex
answers.explanation_why: The external pyramidal layer of the parietal cortex is very vulnerable to ischemic injury. However, neuronal cell death in the dominant parietal cortex would lead to Gerstmann syndrome, not anterograde amnesia as seen here.

Damage to the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus typically leads to anterograde amnesia, as seen in this patient. The hippocampus is the brain region most vulnerable to ischemic hypoxia, and only a few minutes of ischemia can lead to irreversible damage mediated by cytotoxic glutamatergic release and uptake. Other brain regions that are particularly susceptible to ischemic insults are neocortical pyramidal cells, striatal neurons, and Purkinje cells.

Astroglial cells (also known as astrocytes) of the putamen are relatively resistant to ischemic injury mainly because they can use glycogen stores for anaerobic metabolism. Moreover, injury to the cells of the putamen results in impaired voluntary muscle control rather than memory loss. Following an ischemic event, astrocytes become reactive and form a glial scar (reactive gliosis).
