question_text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of generalized fatigue, low-grade fever, and a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows generalized pallor and splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.5 g/dL and leukocyte count is 41,800/mm^3. Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase activity is low. Peripheral blood smear shows basophilia with myelocytes and metamyelocytes. Bone marrow biopsy shows cellular hyperplasia with proliferation of immature granulocytic cells. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of generalized fatigue, low-grade fever, and a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows generalized pallor and splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.5 g/dL and leukocyte count is 41,800/mm3. Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase activity is low. Peripheral blood smear shows basophilia with myelocytes and metamyelocytes. Bone marrow biopsy shows cellular hyperplasia with proliferation of immature granulocytic cells. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's constitutional symptoms (fatigue, fever, weight loss), splenomegaly, anemia, and extreme leukocytosis with midstage progenitor cells (e.g., myelocytes, metamyelocytes) on laboratory evaluation suggest hematologic malignancy. A bone marrow biopsy showing hyperplastic myelopoiesis indicates chronic myeloid leukemia. This is supported by low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase activity, a distinct feature of CML that distinguishes it from all other forms of leukemia.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic myeloid leukemia, and recall its genetic abnormality.

answers.explanation_why: The c-KIT gene is a proto-oncogene that encodes for a receptor with tyrosine kinase activity. Mutations in c-KIT are commonly seen in gastrointestinal stromal tumors but also in acute myeloid leukemia, seminoma, and melanoma. Overexpression of the c-KIT gene is not associated with CML.

answers.content: Cytokine-independent activation of the JAK-STAT pathway
answers.explanation_why: The JAK2 gene encodes intracellular tyrosine kinases involved in activating the JAK-STAT pathway, which controls the proliferation of blood cells from hematopoietic stem cells within the bone marrow. Mutations can cause myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), including essential thrombocythemia, polycythemia vera, primary myelofibrosis, and myelodysplastic syndrome. CML, which this patient likely has, is only rarely caused by JAK2 mutation.

answers.content: Loss of function of the APC gene
answers.explanation_why: The APC gene is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in APC are associated with most cases of sporadic colorectal cancer (via adenoma-carcinoma sequence) and also with familial adenomatous polyposis. Loss of function of the APC gene is not associated with CML.

answers.content: Altered expression of the retinoic acid receptor gene
answers.explanation_why: The retinoic acid receptor (RAR) controls the transcription of genes that are important for cell differentiation beyond the promyelocyte. A t(15;17) translocation causes acute promyelocytic leukemia by altering expression of the retinoic acid receptor gene, which leads to promyelocyte accumulation in the bone marrow with suppression of normal white blood cells. In contrast to this patient, myelocytes and metamyelocytes would not be found on peripheral blood smear and pancytopenia would typically be present. Altered expression of retinoic acid receptor gene is not associated with CML.

answers.content: Unregulated expression of the ABL1 gene
answers.explanation_why: CML is a malignancy of hematopoietic stem cells with excessive proliferation of the myeloid lineage (especially granulocytes). It is caused by a reciprocal translocation that leads to fusion of the ABL gene on chromosome 9 with the BCR gene on chromosome 22, resulting in Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22). The newly formed BCR-ABL fusion gene encodes a BCR-ABL non-receptor tyrosine kinase with increased enzyme activity. The ABL1 gene product inhibits physiologic apoptosis and increases mitotic rate, which promotes uncontrolled proliferation of functioning granulocytes.
answers.explanation_but: The most important therapeutic principle is targeted therapy with imatinib, which selectively inhibits BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase.

question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists for the past several months. Her hands are stiff in the morning; the stiffness improves as she starts her chores. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints. Her range of motion is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists for the past several months. Her hands are stiff in the morning; the stiffness improves as she starts her chores. Physical examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints. Her range of motion is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?
hint: This middle-aged woman has classical symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). She has morning stiffness that improves with activity and polyarticular arthritis (indicated by swelling and tenderness) that involves small joints but spares the DIPs. In addition to non-specific parameters (e.g., increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate), a classic serological finding in some patients is the rheumatoid factor.
learning_objective: Recognize rheumatoid arthritis, and recall its associated autoantibodies.

answers.content: IgM antibodies against the Fc region of IgG
answers.explanation_why:
Rheumatoid factors (RF) are a group of IgM autoantibodies that target the Fc region of IgG. Although elevated RF is classically associated with RA, it has low specificity, since RF elevation may be physiological or caused by other autoimmune and infectious diseases. The level of RF in serum typically increases over the course of RA.

A more specific serological parameter for RA is anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPA).

answers.content: HLA-A3 proteins on white blood cells
answers.explanation_why: HLA-A3 proteins on white blood cells would be increased in hemochromatosis, a condition caused by an autosomal-recessive defect in the HFE gene. Hemochromatosis can manifest with symmetrical arthropathy of the second and third MCP joints, where this patient also has pain. However, this patient does not have the bronze skin tone or any typical complications (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hepatomegaly, liver cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy) seen in hemochromatosis. Furthermore, ESR would not be elevated in hemochromatosis.

answers.content: Membrane proteins that bind to the Fc region of IgG
answers.explanation_why: Protein A is a virulence factor located on the membrane of S. aureus. It targets the Fc region of IgG and protects the bacterial cell from opsonization and phagocytosis. S. aureus can cause septic arthritis and would correspond to an elevated ESR. However, this type of arthritis is typically monoarticular and most commonly affects the knee, hip, wrist, shoulder, and/or ankle. Additionally, septic arthritis would not manifest with morning stiffness, but rather with symptoms of systemic infection such as fever.

answers.content: HLA-B27 protein on white blood cells
answers.explanation_why: The HLA-B27 protein on WBCs is found in seronegative spondyloarthropathies, a group of chronic inflammatory arthritic diseases that can manifest with symmetrical oligoarthritis, morning stiffness that improves with movement, and an elevated ESR. These symptoms are also seen in this patient. However, she does not have the cardinal sign of seronegative spondyloarthropathy – slowly progressive pain in the lower back and sacroiliac joints (especially at night).

answers.content: IgG antibodies with a TNF-α binding domain on the Fc region
answers.explanation_why: Etanercept is a fusion protein that fuses the IgG Fc domain to a TNF-α receptor. This drug binds and inhibits TNF-α and is used in refractory therapy for chronic inflammatory systemic diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis). In rare cases, etanercept might cause an allergic reaction with swelling of the hands, feet, and ankles. However, this reaction would not be characterized by arthralgia and morning stiffness, which this patient has. Additionally, while etanercept is used to treat RA, this patient does not report taking any at the moment.

answers.content: HLA-DQ2 proteins on white blood cells
answers.explanation_why: HLA-DQ2 proteins on WBCs are found in celiac disease, in which hypersensitivity to gluten triggers the production of autoantibodies against tissue transglutaminase in the small intestine. Celiac disease can manifest with a mildly elevated ESR and arthritis, which this patient has. However, arthritis in celiac usually affects the lumbar spine, hips, and knees. Celiac disease may also include symptoms of malabsorption (e.g., vitamin deficiencies and fatigue, and in some individuals weight loss, abdominal pain, or diarrhea) and possibly hormonal or skin complications such as dermatitis herpetiformis, which this patient does not report experiencing.

question_text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening coordination and involuntary movements in her left hand for the past 6 months. Her husband also reports that she has been withdrawn and apathetic during this period. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Examination shows a bimanual, rhythmic, low-frequency tremor that is more prominent in the left hand. There is normal range of motion in the arms and legs; active movements are very slow. Muscle strength is normal, and there is increased resistance to passive flexion and extension in the limbs. She walks with a shuffling gait and takes small steps. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening coordination and involuntary movements in her left hand for the past 6 months. Her husband also reports that she has been withdrawn and apathetic during this period. She is oriented to time, place, and person. Examination shows a bimanual, rhythmic, low-frequency tremor that is more prominent in the left hand. There is normal range of motion in the arms and legs; active movements are very slow. Muscle strength is normal, and there is increased resistance to passive flexion and extension in the limbs. She walks with a shuffling gait and takes small steps. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's muscle rigidity, low-frequency resting tremor, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, and a change in affect are consistent with parkinsonism. Given the unilateral onset of the tremor and the patient's age, the most likely diagnosis is Parkinson disease.
learning_objective: Recognize parkinsonism, and recall the pathophysiology of Parkinson disease.

answers.content: Accumulation of neurotoxic metabolites secondary to hepatocyte damage
answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of neurotoxic metabolites secondary to hepatocyte damage is characteristic of hepatic encephalopathy and must be ruled out in all patients with parkinsonian features, such as the low-frequency hand tremors and mood changes seen in this patient. It is important to note that asterixis is not a true tremor, but rather, myoclonic jerks that typically occur bilaterally in a nonrhythmic manner when the arms and hands are extended. Absence of decompensated liver failure features (e.g., jaundice, ascites) in this patient suggests that her parkinsonian features have a different pathogenesis.

answers.content: Copper accumulation due to mutations in hepatocyte copper-transporting ATPase
answers.explanation_why: A mutation to the copper-transporting ATPases primarily found in the liver (also sparingly seen in the kidneys and brain) is the underlying cause of Wilson disease. This condition is characterized by copper accumulation in the basal ganglia, which can cause parkinsonian features (e.g., resting tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity). Although this patient has parkinsonian symptoms, she does not have the other characteristic findings seen in Wilson disease such as signs of liver disease, Kayser-Fleischer rings, and dysarthria.

answers.content: Neuronal degeneration due to α-synuclein protein misfolding
answers.explanation_why: Neuronal degeneration due to α-synuclein protein misfolding is the hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD), a disease characterized by the presence of eosinophilic inclusions known as Lewy bodies in the soma of neurons. Lewy bodies are aggregates of misfolded α-synuclein and other proteins and are also seen in patients with Lewy body dementia and multiple system atrophy (MSA). Although α-synuclein dysfunction is a key process in PD pathogenesis, the factors instigating neurodegeneration and the selective loss of dopaminergic neurons are multifaceted and still under investigation.

answers.content: Cerebellar ischemia due to chronic hypertension
answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar ischemia due to chronic hypertension is a major risk factor for cerebellar infarction, which may result in a tremor, as seen in this patient. Affected patients usually present with an acute intention tremor, i.e., it worsens with goal-directed movements, which causes dysmetria while performing the finger-nose test. Other signs of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., nystagmus, abnormal gait, dysdiadochokinesia) would also be present. This patient has none of these features and her insidious onset of symptoms suggests that her current condition is of a different pathogenesis.
answers.explanation_but: The blood supply of the cerebellum consists of the posterior inferior cerebellar arteries (PICAs), branches of the vertebral artery, and the anterior inferior cerebellar arteries (AICAs) and the superior cerebellar arteries (SCAs), which arise from the basilar artery. Cerebellar infarcts require special attention because of the danger of cerebral edema within the posterior fossa, which can compress the brain stem causing potentially fatal transtentorial herniation (of the superior vermis through the tentorial notch) or downward herniation of the cerebellar tonsils (through the foramen magnum).

answers.content: Proliferation of beta-adrenergic receptors from excessive circulating T4
answers.explanation_why: Proliferation of β-adrenergic receptors from excessive circulating T4 in patients with hyperthyroidism may result in poorly controlled hypertension, anxiousness, and tremor. However, the tremor seen in hyperthyroidism would be bilateral, of high frequency (10–12 Hz), and not improve with movement.

question_text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for episodic fever, recurrent night sweats, and a 6-kg (14.2-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He reports that the fever lasts for 7 to 10 days, then subsides completely for about a week before returning again. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows nontender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral mediastinal masses. Resection of a cervical lymph node is performed. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Further histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for episodic fever, recurrent night sweats, and a 6-kg (14.2-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He reports that the fever lasts for 7 to 10 days, then subsides completely for about a week before returning again. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows nontender cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral mediastinal masses. Resection of a cervical lymph node is performed. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Further histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient presents with cyclical fever (following a typical Pel-Ebstein pattern), cervical (and likely also mediastinal) lymphadenopathy, and B symptoms. His biopsy shows an inflammatory background featuring large cells that appear to be multinucleated and have prominent nucleoli (Reed-Sternberg cells). These features confirm the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.
learning_objective: Recognize Hodgkin lymphoma, and recall its characteristic cell markers.

answers.content: Cells staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase
answers.explanation_why: Cells staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase are seen in hairy cell leukemia. HCL can manifest with B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, lymphadenopathy is uncommon in HCL, and this patient does not have other characteristic features of this condition (e.g., eponymous hairy cells, symptomatic cytopenia, and massive splenomegaly).

images.title: Hairy cell leukemia
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear sample (H&E stain)A typical hairy cell is visible on the right side of the image. It is significantly bigger than a normal lymphocyte and its membrane has hairy projections (e.g., arrowheads). There is abundant cytoplasm and the nucleus (green overlay) is displaced to one side.The presence of hairy cells in peripheral blood smears is characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.content: Cells staining positive for CD15 and CD30
answers.explanation_why: The lymph node biopsy of this patient with Hodgkin lymphoma shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which stain positive for CD15 and CD30. These large cells have two nuclei, or at least a bilobed nucleus, and prominent nucleoli surrounded by pale halos (owl-eye appearance), as seen in the biopsy specimen here. They are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma and confirm the diagnosis. Other histological findings in Hodgkin lymphoma include granuloma formation and an inflammatory background that contains the following cell types in varying numbers: lymphocytes, eosinophils, neutrophils, macrophages/histiocytes, plasma cells, and fibroblasts.

images.title: Hodgkin lymphoma (immunohistochemistry for CD30)
images.description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Cells with a BCR-ABL rearrangement are a characteristic finding of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). CML can manifest with B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, lymphadenopathy would not be expected. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common features of CML, such as basophilia, extreme leukocytosis, or a peripheral blood smear showing mid-stage progenitor cells (e.g., promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes).

images.title: Left shift to promyelocyte stage in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
images.description: Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain; very high magnification)A typical finding in chronic myelogenous leukemia is marked leukocytosis with a spectrum of neutrophils in different stages of maturation, usually not seen in the peripheral blood.Seg: mature segmented neutrophils; St: stab cells/band cells; PM: promyelocytes; L: lymphocytes; P: platelets

answers.explanation_why: Cells overexpressing Bcl-2 are seen in follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Either disease can manifest with painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms, which are seen in this patient. However, the pathological findings would differ from those seen here. Biopsy in follicular lymphoma would reveal densely packed lymphoid follicles with small cleaved cells, while biopsy in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma would typically show a diffuse growth pattern and large lymphocytes.

images.title: Follicular lymphoma (peripheral blood smear)
images.description: Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.explanation_why: Cells with a t(8;14) chromosomal translocation are typically seen in Burkitt lymphoma, which can manifest with the painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms seen in this patient. However, this patient's Pel-Ebstein fever pattern would be atypical in Burkitt lymphoma. Furthermore, biopsy would typically show a starry sky pattern instead of the Reed-Sternberg cells found here.

images.title: Hodgkin lymphoma
images.description: Photomicrograph of a lymph node biopsy specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)A Reed–Sternberg cell (green overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. It is surrounded by numerous lymphocytes (examples indicated by arrowheads).This histopathological appearance is characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
hint: Giant, multinucleated histiocytes (globoid cells) on histopathologic examination of the brain are diagnostic of Krabbe disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Krabbe disease, and recall the enzyme deficiency it involves.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of sphingomyelinase, which leads to an accumulation of sphingomyelin mainly in the brain, liver, spleen and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Niemann-Pick disease (NPD). This condition can manifest with seizures and progressive neurodegeneration with brain atrophy. However, NPD is typically associated with hypotonia (not hypertonia), a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (rather than optic disc pallor), interstitial lung disease, and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which is seen here. Moreover, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of NPD.

A deficiency of arylsulfatase A, which leads to an accumulation of cerebroside sulfate mainly in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in metachromatic leukodystrophy (ML). ML can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), brain and optic atrophy (optic pallor and vision loss), seizures, and loss of glial cells on brain biopsy, all of which are seen in this patient. However, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of this condition. Moreover, ML typically also manifests with ataxia and hypotonia (not hypertonia), which are not seen here.

A deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase, which leads to an accumulation of glucocerebroside in the brain, liver, spleen, and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Gaucher disease. Some patients with this condition present with neurological complications such as developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), loss of vision (from macular atrophy and uveitis), and seizures. However, Gaucher disease is not associated with brain or optic atrophy (optic disc pallor) or globoid cells on brain biopsy. Instead, typical manifestations of Gaucher disease include hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, painful bone crises, and pathological fractures, none of which is seen here.

A deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to an accumulation of GM_2 ganglioside mainly in the brain and retina, is the primary defect in Tay-Sachs disease (TSD). This condition can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), vision loss, and seizures. However, TSD is typically also associated with muscle weakness and hypotonia (not hypertonia), hyperreflexia, hearing impairment and a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (not optic disc pallor), none of which is present here. Moreover, brain biopsy of a patient with TSD typically reveals lysosomes with an onion skin appearance, not globoid cells.

A deficiency of β-galactocerebrosidase, which leads to intracellular accumulation of myelin breakdown products (galactocerebroside and psychosine) in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in Krabbe disease. Characteristic pathologic findings resulting from the toxic effect of these breakdown products include globoid cells and progressive loss of myelin sheaths. Krabbe disease most commonly manifests in early infancy with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), fever, limb spasticity, brain and optic atrophy (optic disc pallor and vision loss), and seizures, as seen in this patient. Further symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, axial hypotonia, absent reflexes, and microcephaly. Progressive decerebration usually leads to death before the age of two.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been shown to improve outcomes if performed before the onset of symptoms.

images.title: Lysosomal storage disease
images.description: The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of α-galactosidase A is the primary defect in Fabry disease and leads to an accumulation of ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide) in the endothelium of vessels, the epithelium of many organs, and smooth muscle cells. This condition classically manifests during late childhood with paresthesias and neuropathic pain, hypohidrosis, angiokeratomas, asymptomatic cataracts, and gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient's presentation is not consistent with Fabry disease.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of tingling and weakness in the lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows areflexia of the ankle and knee joints bilaterally. Motor strength is 1/5 in both lower legs. Over the next 3 weeks, the patient's condition progresses to involve both upper extremities, and she requires ventilatory support. Six weeks after admission, deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the ankles, and she is able to wiggle her toes. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the improvement in this patient's neurological status?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of tingling and weakness in the lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows areflexia of the ankle and knee joints bilaterally. Motor strength is 1/5 in both lower legs. Over the next 3 weeks, the patient's condition progresses to involve both upper extremities, and she requires ventilatory support. Six weeks after admission, deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the ankles, and she is able to wiggle her toes. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the improvement in this patient's neurological status?
hint: This patient had Guillain-Barré syndrome, a condition that causes acute-onset distal paresthesias with symmetrical, ascending lower motor neuron weakness.
learning_objective: Recognize Guillain-Barré syndrome, and recall the process of nerve recovery.

answers.explanation_why: The synthesis of monoamine neurotransmitters is impaired in patients with neuropsychiatric disorders such as major depressive disorder. Neurotransmitter synthesis is not involved in the recovery process from Guillain-Barré syndrome.

The underlying pathology of Guillain-Barré syndrome is a postinfectious, autoimmune reaction that generates cross-reactive antibodies that demyelinate peripheral nerve axons. Disease progression peaks 2–4 weeks after the onset of symptoms. Peripheral nerve axons then undergo remyelination by Schwann cells over a duration of weeks to months, and symptoms recede in reverse order of their development (i.e., functionality is restored in a descending pattern, in contrast to the ascending pattern of paralysis).

In addition to supportive management, high doses of intravenous immunoglobulins and plasmapheresis can be used to shorten the time to recovery.

Oligodendrocyte precursor cells replicate during the recovery process after an exacerbation of multiple sclerosis, a condition that causes hyperreflexia (not the hyporeflexia seen in this case). Oligodendrocytes synthesize myelin in the central nervous system and are not involved in the recovery process from Guillain-Barré syndrome, which affects the peripheral nervous system.

The accumulation of S-adenosylmethionine is part of the underlying pathology of peripheral neuropathy caused by vitamin B_6 deficiency, a condition that can be induced by isoniazid therapy and oral contraceptive use. It is not involved in the recovery process from Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Lymphocytic infiltration in the endoneurium of peripheral nerves is part of the underlying pathology of Guillain-Barré syndrome. This autoimmune reaction generates cross-reactive antibodies that damage peripheral nerve axons. Lymphocytic infiltration is not involved in the recovery process from this condition.

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a 6-week history of fatigue, fever, and recurrent epistaxis. She has a history of duodenal atresia and an atrioventricular septal defect. She is at the 5^th percentile for height and 30^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Her hands are short and broad and there is a space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. Bone marrow aspirate shows leukocytosis with 50% lymphoblasts. Which of the following best explains this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a 6-week history of fatigue, fever, and recurrent epistaxis. She has a history of duodenal atresia and an atrioventricular septal defect. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Her hands are short and broad and there is a space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. Bone marrow aspirate shows leukocytosis with 50% lymphoblasts. Which of the following best explains this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's clinical findings (fatigue, fever, recurrent epistaxis, painless cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly) and laboratory findings (leukocytosis with lymphoblasts) are consistent with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). ALL, duodenal atresia, atrioventricular septal defect, short stature, broad hands, and sandal gap are common manifestations of trisomy 21.
learning_objective: Recognize acute lymphocytic leukemia associated with trisomy 21, and recall the genetic mechanism of trisomy 21.

answers.explanation_why: A frameshift mutation in the X-linked dystrophin gene causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which causes muscle weakness and dilated cardiomyopathy. DMD is not associated with an increased risk of ASD, duodenal atresia, or leukemia. A frameshift mutation is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

Meiotic nondisjunction is a pathologic genetic mechanism that can lead to chromosomal aberrations. 95% of cases of trisomy 21 are caused by the meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21. In the majority of these cases, this nondisjunction occurs in meiosis I (70%). In 20% of cases, the nondisjunction occurs in meiosis II. In 5% of cases, it is due to paternal non-disjunction during spermatogenesis.

Deletion of a segment on chromosome 5 can lead to cri-du-chat syndrome. This genetic disease manifests with congenital heart defects (most commonly ventricular septal defect), intellectual disability, facial and skeletal malformations, and, most characteristically, a high-pitched voice. This patient has a history of an ASD, duodenal stenosis, and ALL, which are not typically seen in patients with cri-du-chat syndrome. Deletion of a chromosome segment is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

Uniparental disomy is responsible for 25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome and 5% of cases of Angelman syndrome. These syndromes may manifest with short stature, as seen in this patient. However, neither of these conditions is associated with duodenal atresia, ASD, or ALL, and other common manifestations of these syndromes such as obesity, muscular hypotonia, epileptic seizures, and/or behavioral problems are not described in this patient. Uniparental disomy is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

Mosaicism is a genetic condition that can cause trisomy 21. However, it is a very rare cause, accounting for about 1% of cases. Additionally, ALL, duodenal stenosis, and atrioventricular septal defect are less common in mosaic trisomy 21 because not all cells have the characteristic chromosomal aberration, which usually results in less severe symptoms.
answers.explanation_but: Mosaicism is more common (50%) in patients with Turner syndrome, which can cause short stature, specific cardiac defects (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve, aortic coarctation) as well as an increased risk of certain tumors (e.g., cystic hygroma, ovarian gonadoblastoma).

answers.explanation_why: Trinucleotide repeat expansion is a pathologic mechanism of Friedreich ataxia, fragile X syndrome, and myotonic dystrophy, which are associated with specific cardiac abnormalities (e.g., mitral valve prolapse in Fragile X syndrome, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in Friedreich ataxia, arrhythmias in myotonic dystrophy). None of these conditions are, however, associated with an increased risk of ASD, duodenal atresia, or ALL. Trinucleotide repeat expansion is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation is a genetic variation that involves a translocation (genetics) of the long arms of acrocentric chromosomes, which is one possible genetic change leading to trisomy 21. However, this variation is relatively uncommon and is only found in about 4% of individuals with trisomy 21.

question_text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. Over the past 3 days, he has had a fever and worsening headaches. This morning, his wife noticed that he was irritable and demonstrated strange behavior; he put the back of his fork, the salt shaker, and the lid of the coffee can into his mouth. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows diffuse hyperreflexia and an extensor response to the plantar reflex on the right. A T2-weighted MRI of the brain shows edema and areas of hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema in this patient?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. Over the past 3 days, he has had a fever and worsening headaches. This morning, his wife noticed that he was irritable and demonstrated strange behavior; he put the back of his fork, the salt shaker, and the lid of the coffee can into his mouth. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows diffuse hyperreflexia and an extensor response to the plantar reflex on the right. A T2-weighted MRI of the brain shows edema and areas of hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema in this patient?
hint: The patient’s history of fever, headaches, seizure, focal neurologic findings (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex), and MRI showing edema and hemorrhage in the temporal lobe suggest HSV encephalitis.
learning_objective: Recognize HSV encephalitis, and recall the pathologic mechanism underlying vasogenic edema.

answers.content: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor
answers.explanation_why: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor is one of the pathologic mechanisms of edema in brain tumors. This patient’s headache, seizure, and focal neurologic deficits are early signs of a brain tumor. However, an acute onset of symptoms and fever are more consistent with an infectious etiology.

Cellular retention of sodium leading to fluid retention and cellular swelling is the pathologic mechanism of cytotoxic edema, a complication of acute ischemic stroke. Ischemic stroke can manifest with headache, seizure, and focal neurologic findings (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex). However, T2-weighted MRI in acute ischemic stroke typically shows hyperintensity with no hemorrhages. Furthermore, an acute ischemic stroke would not explain this patient's fever.

Breakdown of endothelial tight junctions causing damage to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is the pathologic mechanism underlying vasogenic edema. Disruption of the BBB leads to extravasation of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space of the cerebral parenchyma, leading to increased intracranial pressure and neuronal dysfunction. This mechanism of edema development can also be due to other inflammatory conditions, metastasis, trauma, or lead poisoning.

The patient's behavioral change (putting the fork, salt shaker, and coffee can lid in his mouth) is characteristic of hyperorality, a finding in Kluver-Bucy syndrome. This condition is a possible complication of HSV encephalitis.

Degranulation of eosinophils is part of the pathologic mechanism of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction is characterized by tissue swelling and edema due to increased histamine release and increased vascular permeability. However, this mechanism does not play a role in the pathophysiology of cerebral edema.

Increased hydrostatic pressure is the pathologic mechanism underlying hypertensive encephalopathy, which causes severe headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex). However, hypertensive encephalopathy does not typically cause fever. Furthermore, this patient’s blood pressure is within the normal range.

question_text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 1 month. He has been unable to practice with his recreational soccer team and has had to rest frequently when walking to work. His only medication is ibuprofen for joint pain. Physical examination shows tanned skin. There is tenderness to palpation and stiffness of the metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. Pulmonary examination shows coarse crackles in both lung fields. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing is most likely to be positive for which of the following?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 1 month. He has been unable to practice with his recreational soccer team and has had to rest frequently when walking to work. His only medication is ibuprofen for joint pain. Physical examination shows tanned skin. There is tenderness to palpation and stiffness of the metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. Pulmonary examination shows coarse crackles in both lung fields. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing is most likely to be positive for which of the following?
hint: This patient has features of heart failure (e.g., fatigue, exertional dyspnea, coarse crackles in both lung fields). These findings, in addition to cutaneous hyperpigmentation, hepatomegaly, and joint pain, are suspicious for a diagnosis of hemochromatosis.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary hemochromatosis, and recall its associated HLA subtype.

answers.explanation_why: HLA-B27 is associated with seronegative arthritides (i.e., inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis), which can cause joint pain and fatigue. This patient does not have gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, abdominal pain) that raise suspicion for an underlying inflammatory bowel disease. Ankylosing spondylitis is a form of arthritis that primarily affects the axial skeleton (e.g., spine, sacroiliac joint) rather than the small joints of the hands. In the other seronegative arthritides, the distal joints are most commonly involved but are affected asymmetrically (in contrast to this patient, who has symmetrical arthropathy). Moreover, this patient does not have psoriatic lesions or a history of recent genitourinary infection to suggest a diagnosis of these other seronegative arthritides.

HLA-DR3 is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Addison disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), Hashimoto thyroiditis, and Graves disease. SLE can cause fatigue, symmetrical small joint arthropathy, postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (due to photosensitivity), and dyspnea with crackles due to lung or heart involvement. However, it does not cause hepatomegaly and more commonly occurs among women. Addison disease, T1DM, and Hashimoto thyroiditis can cause fatigue; in addition, Addison disease causes hyperpigmentation, and Hashimoto thyroiditis can cause joint pain. However, this patient does not have other characteristic features of these conditions (e.g., weight loss, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms in Addison disease; weight loss and polyuria in T1DM; goiter and weight gain in Hashimoto thyroiditis). None of these conditions cause hepatomegaly or crackles. Graves disease causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance), which are not seen in this patient.

HLA-DR4 is associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), Addison disease, and type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). RA causes metacarpophalangeal (MCP) arthropathy and fatigue. Dyspnea with crackles can also occur in patients RA as a result of lung involvement. However, RA does not cause cutaneous hyperpigmentation and more commonly occurs among women. In addition, hepatomegaly is not a typical initial manifestation of RA. Addison disease causes fatigue and diffuse hyperpigmentation, but it does not cause MCP arthropathy, hepatomegaly, or pulmonary manifestations; in addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Addison disease, such as weight loss, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms. T1DM can cause fatigue, but it typically manifests before 30 years of age and is associated with additional symptoms, such as weight loss and polyuria, which are not seen in this patient.

HLA-B8 is associated with Addison disease, myasthenia gravis, and Graves disease. Addison disease causes fatigue and hyperpigmentation but does not cause arthropathy, hepatomegaly, or pulmonary manifestations. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Addison disease, such as weight loss, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Myasthenia gravis can cause fatigue and dyspnea (due to diaphragmatic weakness), but it does not cause arthropathy, crackles, hepatomegaly, or hyperpigmentation. Graves disease causes features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance), which are not seen in this patient.

HLA-A3 is associated with hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which is caused by an autosomal recessive HFE gene defect that leads to abnormal iron sensing and increased intestinal iron absorption. The clinical features of HH are caused by organ iron overload. Iron deposition in the heart can lead to either dilated or restrictive cardiomyopathy. Deposition in the skin causes hyperpigmentation. Accumulation of iron in the joints leads to articular damage and promotes calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition; the metacarpophalangeal joints are classically involved. Deposition in the liver leads to hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, and increased risk for hepatocellular carcinoma, which is the most common cause of death in patients with HH. Other manifestations of HH include diabetes mellitus and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

images.title: Pathophysiology of hemochromatosis
images.description: Left: Iron homeostasis is regulated by the HFE gene. HFE regulates levels of hepcidin, a protein that reduces the transport of iron from the cells to the bloodstream via the ferroportin transport protein.Right: Hemochromatosis results from the mutation of the HFE gene → reduced hepcidin production → unregulated ferroportin activity → iron accumulation throughout the body → end-organ damage
